83076.description: One of two silver plated brass andirons with urn-form finials with applied male masks above tapering square shafts with relief bellflowers. Fluted tapering legs with urn finials.

83076.provenance: Andirons and their attached log supports are part of the gift of the house and contents to the Art Association of Indianapolis from J.K. Lilly Jr. as shown by being "Susan Hallis" (SH) items. They are pictured in the visual SH inventory, but are not listed as having accession numbers in the SH list. Historic photographs from the 1930s and 1960s show this suite of fireplace equipment in the dining room.

11288.title: day dress
11288.description: pale pink silk chiffon, trimmed with pink silk velvet, pink silk chiffon ruching and appliqued silk embroidered flowers; lined with pink silk taffeta and chiffon
11288.credit_line: Gift of Carolyn Garrigues Scofield in memory of her grandmother Caroline Burford Danner
11288.provenance:
Caroline Burford Danner {1}, Indianapolis; through Carolyn Garrigues Scofield, Rhode Island; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (1986).
{1} Caroline Burford Danner is the grandmother of Carolyn Garrigues Scofield
11288.inscription: G. Giuseffi L. T. Company, St. Louis, MO.

extended_text.content:
The appliquéd and cutout stylized flowers—either peonies or plum blossoms—are drawn in an Art Nouveau style, which was prevalent from 1890 to 1914. The dramatic sleeve silhouette along with the great amount of ruching and hand pin tucking throughout the bodice and skirt make this a very expensive garment, perhaps part of a trousseau.

The period from 1900 until the outbreak of World War I in 1914 was an era of beautiful, extravagant, and ultra-feminine clothes. The high-collared bodice and the soft, draping trained skirt were worn over an S-shaped corset. The corset pushed the bust forward and the hips backward, creating an S-curve in the silhouette of the body.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

11288.exhibit_history:
Fashion in Bloom
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, IMA
April 4, 2009 - January 31, 2010

31951.title: Firelight (Francisco Martinez)
31951.title_notes: See 3/20/2015 entry in Tasks field regarding the title and Rebecca McNamara's research notes in the historical fie.
31951.credit_line: Gift of the Harrison Eiteljorg Gallery of Western Art
31951.inscription: Signed and dated, l.r.: J H. SHARP. 13

extended_text.content:
This is an idealized portrait of a seventeen-year-old Indian boy who later became Chief of the Taos Pueblo.

The boy is shown drying a bird's brain to create a talisman that will guarantee his future success.

Sharp documented Indian tribal life and ritual.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

31951.exhibit_history: Art of the American West (The West as Inspiration), Eiteljorg Museum of Indian and Western Art, Indianapolis, Indiana, 05/1989-03/26/2004| The Painters of Taos:  Selections from the Collection of Harrison Eiteljorg, Sierra Nevada Museum of Art, Reno, Nevada, 06/25/1985-08/18/1985| The Painters of Taos:  Selections from the Collection of Harrison Eiteljorg, Palm Springs Desert Museum, Palm Springs, California, 11/01/1984-03/30/1985|

72311.title: textile panel; 'diagonals'
72311.title_notes: Environmental Enrichment Interior Panels for Herman Miller
72311.creation_notes:
collection: Environmental Enrichment Interior Panels for Herman Miller
Design rough cut number: 3037
72311.description: A screen printed fabric panel with a pattern of red-orange diagonal lines on an undyed plain weave cotton ground.  The textile is wrapped around a piece of 1 inch plywood with rounded corners and appears to be attached to the plywood with a paste/starch type adhesive.  Staples are only present at the four corners.  A rectangular frame of black painted wood is nailed to the reverse of the plywood, an inch or so in from the edge, to block the piece away from the wall when it is hung.  There are no selvedges present; the fabric has cut raw edges all around.
72311.credit_line: Gift of Irwin Management Company, Inc.
72311.medium_support: cotton, silk screen ink or dye
72311.provenance: Alexander Girard for Herman Miller Furniture Company; Irwin Management Company, Inc., Columbus, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2012.
72311.inscription: Stamp, screen printed, at bottom of lower proper left side: Alexander Girard 1972
